content.text: Small drops of water fall at regular intervals from a leaking tap (faucet)
Fig. 1.1
Immediately after a drop has fallen, a student puts an empty measuring cylinder under the tap, to catch the drops
At the same time, her friend starts a stopwatch
After 50 drops have fallen, she stops the stopwatch
Fig. 1.2 shows the reading on the stopwatch at the start and finish of this experiment
Fig. 1.3 shows the measuring cylinder at the finish
Fig. 1.3
Suggest which liquid is contained in the barometer
What occupies the space in the tube, above the liquid?
Three distances are marked on Fig. 2.1
Which distance enables the atmospheric pressure to be deduced?
The atmospheric pressure increases
State one of the three marked distances that decreases
The tube is accidentally knocked at the top, so that a small crack is caused at the top of the tube. Air leaks in through the crack
Describe what effect, if any, this has on the level of the liquid in the tube
Fig. 2.1 shows a simple barometer. The vertical tube is fixed in position
On Fig. 3.1, two of the changes have been labelled. In the empty boxes, label the other two changes
In terms of molecules and temperatures, describe what happens during melting
What name do we give to this temperature?
At what temperature does solid water (ice) turn back to liquid water?
Pure water turns from liquid to solid at \(0^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\)
The arrows on Fig. 3.1 indicate the changes between the three states of matter
Explain why metals are able to conduct electricity well, whereas insulators, like are very poor conductors
A plastic rod is rubbed with a dry cloth, as shown in Fig. 4.1
After this, the rod is held close to a girl's long hair. The hair is attracted to the rod
Suggest why this happens

current =   .........

1. ammeter X,
2. ammeter Y

reading =   .........  V
Fig. 5.1 shows a circuit with two ammeters, X and Y
A technician has an unmagnetised steel rod
Describe how the technician can permanently magnetise the steel rod
The technician places two magnets on a bench, in the positions shown in Fig. 6.1
Which of the following describes the magnetic force between the magnets? Tick one box
The technician now places an unmagnetised iron rod between the magnets, as shown in Fig. 6.2
On Fig. 6.2, label the N pole and the S pole induced on the iron rod
Finally, the technician places one magnet and a charged plastic rod on the bench shown in Fig. 6.3
Which of the following describes the magnetic force between the magnet and the rod? Tick one box
Waves are either transverse or longitudinal
Write either "transverse" or "longitudinal" in the space alongside each of the following descriptions

table.html:
descriptiontype of wave
This type of wave has vibrations at right angles to the direction in which the wave energy is travelling.
This type of wave has vibrations along the direction in which the wave energy is travelling.
A sound wave is an example of this type of wave.
A ripple on the surface of water is an example of this type of wave.

content.text: When air is present in the bell-jar, the electric bell can be heard ringing clearly
What properties of sound does this observation illustrate? Tick the box alongside any appropriate answer
sound travels through air
sound travels through glass
sound travels faster than light
sound travels infinitely fast
As the vacuum pump removes the air from the bell-jar, the sound becomes quieter. Eventually the sound cannot be heard at all, even though the bell can still be seen to be working
Suggest what property of sound this observation demonstrates

Which of these three quantities needs to be as low as possible in order to keep the efficiency of the machine as high as possible?
the useful energy output \(U\),
the wasted energy \(W\),
the efficiency of the machine
The machine gets older and parts of it become worn

Fig. 10.1 illustrates the energy into and out of a machine
The \(\alpha\) -particle source in Fig. 11.1 is placed \(1 \text{cm}\) from a radiation detector connected to a rate meter. The rate meter gives a count-rate reading of 600 counts/min
The source is then moved to a distance of \(50 \text{cm}\) from the detector and the count-rate reading on the rate meter becomes 25 counts/min
Predict what the count-rate will be when the source is moved to a distance of \(100 \text{cm}\) from the detector. Explain your answer
explanation
An adjustment to the rollers is made and the foil becomes thicker
What happens to the rate at which \(\beta\) -particles are detected?
Assuming that all suitable safety precautions are taken, explain
1. why \(\alpha\) -particles would not be suitable in this application,
2. why \(\gamma\) -rays would not be suitable in this application
Fig. 11.2 shows aluminium being rolled into a thin sheet suitable for cooking foil. \(\beta\) -particles are being used to monitor and control the thickness of the foil
State the meaning of the nucleon number of a nuclide

State
1. the nucleon number of an \(\alpha\) -particle,
2. the proton number of an \(\alpha\) -particle
In nuclide notation, the thorium nucleus formed is written as \(^{X}_{Y}\mathrm{Th}\)
State the values of
A nucleus of \(^{238}_{92}\mathrm{U}\) decays by emitting an \(\alpha\) -particle. It becomes a nucleus of thorium (Th)
How many electrons are to be found in a neutral atom of \(^{238}_{92}\mathrm{U}\)?
Where in the atom are these electrons to be found?
The nucleus of uranium-238 is represented in nuclide notation as \(^{238}_{92}\mathrm{U}\)
